channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Murdered Keanu 'failed' by agencies
item.description: A serious case review into the murder of two-year-old Keanu Williams finds police, social services and health workers "failed" to prevent his death.

item.title: Dozens die in Italy boat sinking
item.description: At least 94 African migrants die as a boat carrying them to Europe sinks off the southern Italian island of Lampedusa, local officials say.

item.title: Mail on Sunday apology to Miliband
item.description: The editor of the Mail on Sunday apologises for a reporter intruding into a private memorial service for a relative of Ed Miliband, as two journalists are suspended.

item.title: IMF says US must solve debt crisis
item.description: IMF managing director Christine Lagarde says failure to raise the debt ceiling is a far worse threat to global economy than the current government shutdown.

item.title: Payday lenders face tougher rules
item.description: The UK's payday lenders have been warned that tougher regulation is on its way, to protect consumers.

item.title: GP services 'face cuts catastrophe'
item.description: The GP system in England is facing a "catastrophe" because of cuts in funding that represent a £400m drop in real terms, doctors' leaders warn.

item.title: Hamzah Khan jury considers verdict
item.description: The jury in the case of a mother-of-eight accused of killing her son Hamzah Khan in Bradford retires to consider its verdict.

item.title: UK regrets Gambia Commonwealth exit
item.description: The Gambia's decision to withdraw from the Commonwealth 48 years after joining is something to "very much regret", the UK Foreign Office says.

item.title: Plane crashes after Lagos take-off
item.description: At least 13 people are killed in Nigeria as a small passenger plane crashes shortly after take-off from Lagos airport, officials say.

item.title: Health of oceans 'declining fast'
item.description: The health of the world’s oceans is deteriorating even faster than scientists previously thought, a report says.

item.title: More children pass new phonics test
item.description: More children have passed the new phonics test for England's five- and six-year-olds this year.

item.title: Lotto ticket price doubles to £2
item.description: Camelot, which runs the National Lottery, increases the price of a Lotto ticket to £2, the first rise since the game began in 1994.

item.title: Pollution 'hampers bees' foraging'
item.description: Honeybees' ability to find flowers could be hampered by a chemical in diesel exhaust, say scientists.

item.title: O'Connor writes open letter to Cyrus
item.description: Singer Sinead O'Connor has written an open letter to Miley Cyrus urging her not to let the music business "make a prostitute of you".

item.title: Farrow paternity story 'absurd'
item.description: Speculation that Frank Sinatra and not Woody Allen may be the father of Mia Farrow's 25-year-old son Ronan is dismissed by both Allen's spokesman and Sinatra's widow.

item.title: Fewer children owning mobile phones
item.description: The number of children owning mobile phones has fallen for the first time, according to figures from the regulator, Ofcom.

item.title: VIDEO: Why Heathrow travel costs more
item.description: The aviation regulator has proposed capping landing fees at Heathrow Airport - travel expert Simon Calder

item.title: Benefit cap hits 8,400 households
item.description: The government's cap on the total amount of benefits a non-working household can receive is affecting 8,400 households, figures show.

item.title: VIDEO: UKIP's Bashir rejects 'racist' claims
item.description: UKIP's spokesman on small business said the media were "doing no good service to this country" with claims of racism about his party.

item.title: Exercise 'can be as good as pills'
item.description: Exercise can be as good a medicine as pills for people with conditions such as heart disease, a study finds.

item.title: VIDEO: Disabled students 'need more help'
item.description: Students with disabilities are struggling to take part in university life because staff are not offering them enough support, a charity says.

item.title: Teachers in China 'highest status'
item.description: Teachers in China are the most highly respected, in an international study comparing the status of teachers in 21 countries.

item.title: VIDEO: Major artworks tour UK schools
item.description: Masterpieces by Lowry and Monet have been touring schools around Britain as part of an initiative to inspire young people.

item.title: Bitcoin falls after Silk Road arrest
item.description: The price of bitcoins, a virtual currency, has fallen following to closure of the clandestine Silk Road website by the FBI.

item.title: VIDEO: What is Bitcoin?
item.description: The value of the virtual currency Bitcoin has plummeted following an FBI raid on the shady Silk Road online marketplace.

item.title: Top five physics discoveries chosen
item.description: Quantum computers and the science that could enable mobile phones to be charged by shoes are among the "top five physics spin-offs" chosen by a leading magazine.

item.title: VIDEO: How to test a bee's sense of smell
item.description: Researchers use a bee "sniff test" to work out that diesel exhaust pollution diminishes the insects' ability to smell flowers.

item.title: Diana reviews 'devastated' director
item.description: The director of Diana says he has "no regrets", despite the film's "devastating" reviews in the UK.

item.title: VIDEO: Ray Davies hints at Kinks reunion
item.description: Musician Ray Davies has told BBC Breakfast that the Kinks could get back together and record some new material

item.title: Can we teach kindness?
item.description: Would you give up your seat to someone unable to stand? We may say we would, but we don't always. Is this just human nature, or can we be taught to be kind?

item.title: Do people get their politics from their parents?
item.description: Ed Miliband is locked in a row with the Daily Mail over his father's views. But to what extent are our political opinions shaped by our parents?

item.title: Hart is my number one, says Hodgson
item.description: England boss Roy Hodgson gives his full backing to Joe Hart, insisting the goalkeeper has "never let me down".

item.title: Fifa prepared for Qatar vote delay
item.description: Fifa is expected to agree to move the 2022 World Cup from its traditional slot on the football calendar - but only after proper talks have taken place.

item.title: Bale withdraws from Wales squad
item.description: Wales confirm that Gareth Bale will miss their final two World Cup qualifiers despite naming the Real Madrid forward in their squad.

item.title: Formula 1 officials monitoring storm
item.description: Formula 1 organisers are monitoring a tropical storm that is passing through parts of Asia ahead of Sunday's Korean Grand Prix.

item.title: Olympian Joshua must learn from Harrison's mistakes
item.description: Olympic gold medallist Anthony Joshua turns pro on Saturday aiming to avoid the mistakes made by Audley Harrison

item.title: Council agrees equal pay claims
item.description: Birmingham City Council says it has reached an agreement with the joint trade unions to settle about 11,000 equal pay claims.

item.title: Fifty left sick after wedding party
item.description: A newlywed couple's homecoming party is thought to have left 50 people violently sick.

item.title: Landslip closes A83 after heavy rain
item.description: The A83 at the Rest and be Thankful in Argyll is closed by a landslip - for the seventh time in five years.

item.title: Glasgow health board IT system fixed
item.description: Scotland's largest health board says its IT system is working again after a two-day crash saw hundreds of appointments and procedures cancelled.

item.title: Call centre firm creates 993 jobs
item.description: Almost 1,000 jobs are being created by a call centre company in east Belfast.

item.title: Man admits Derry teenager murder
item.description: A 27-year-old man is sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder of his former partner's sister.

item.title: Demolition of city mural under way
item.description: A historic artwork in the centre of Newport is being demolished days after attempts to have it preserved for its architectural significance failed.

item.title: 86 charged in 'crash for cash' probe
item.description: A total of 86 people are charged in relation to an alleged "crash for cash" insurance scam after a two-year inquiry by police and fraud investigators.

item.title: Madagascar mob kills two Europeans
item.description: Angry protesters in Madagascar burn to death two European men they suspected of trafficking human organs after a child went missing.

item.title: DNA tests for Kenya mall relatives
item.description: Relatives of people missing after the attack on a Kenyan mall come forward for DNA testing after body parts were discovered.

item.title: Worker error causes Fukushima leak
item.description: Japan's crippled Fukushima nuclear plant has a new leak of radioactive water after workers overfilled a storage tank, its operator says.

item.title: India jails corrupt former minister
item.description: Former Indian railways minister Laloo Prasad Yadav is sent to jail for five years in what is being seen as a landmark step in the fight against corruption.

item.title: Russia 'targets Sochi migrants'
item.description: Human Rights Watch accuses Russia of rounding up hundreds of migrant workers who helped build 2014 Winter Olympics sites in Sochi.

item.title: France approves 'anti-Amazon' bill
item.description: France has approved a bill to support independent bookstores against competition from online retailers, such as Amazon.

item.title: Colombia 'can reintegrate rebels'
item.description: The head of the Colombian Agency for Reintegration tells the BBC that Colombia is ready to receive tens of thousands of demobilised rebels.

item.title: Mexico police clash with protesters
item.description: Riot police clash with protesters in Mexico City during a demonstration commemorating the 45th anniversary of the Tlatelolco massacre.

item.title: UN in humanitarian call to Syria
item.description: The UN Security Council - speaking once again in a united voice - urges Syrian authorities to allow access amid a worsening humanitarian situation.

item.title: Pro-Morsi pupil dies in Suez clashes
item.description: A teenage boy has been killed in clashes in the Egyptian city of Suez between supporters and opponents of the deposed president, Mohammed Morsi.

item.title: White House talks fail over shutdown
item.description: White House talks between President Obama and Congressional leaders fail to break a budget deadlock that has led to a partial government shutdown.

item.title: Jackson family lose negligence case
item.description: The family of Michael Jackson loses a negligence case brought against concert promoters AEG Live over the death of the star.

item.title: Your pictures: Motoring
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of motoring

item.title: Day in pictures: 3 October 2013
item.description: 24 hours of news photographs: 3 October

item.title: In pictures: My generation
item.description: Thriving punk and squat scene in 1980s Leeds

item.title: In pictures: India's Ambassador taxis
item.description: India's 'virtually indestructible' taxi

item.title: Day in pictures: 2 October 2013
item.description: 24 hours of news photographs: 2 October

item.title: Your Pictures: Photos from Wales
item.description: Your digital photos from around Wales

item.title: In pictures: Anglo-Saxon treasures
item.description: Excavation of an Anglo-Saxon monastic site

item.title: Day in pictures: 1 October 2013
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 1 October

item.title: VIDEO: Dozens drown as migrant boat sinks
item.description: At least 92 people have been killed after a boat carrying as many as 500 migrants from Africa caught fire and sank just off the Italian island of Lampedusa in the early hours of Thursday morning.

item.title: VIDEO: Designer Gromits go under the hammer
item.description: More than 80 giant statues of Wallace's canine companion Gromit which have been on display at an exhibition in Bristol will be auctioned for charity later.

item.title: VIDEO: Parents: Piracy charges 'ludicrous'
item.description: The parents of a film maker charged with piracy by the Russian authorities have described the charges as "ludicrous".

item.title: VIDEO: Huge pylons get new coat of paint
item.description: A team of specialists near the end of a 13-week project to repaint two electricity pylons which span the Severn Estuary.

item.title: VIDEO: Activists chained to fuel pumps
item.description: Greenpeace activists in Germany have staged demonstrations to protest against the detention of 30 of their colleagues in Russia.

item.title: VIDEO: Cyclist's near miss with train
item.description: A cyclist came within seconds of death after failing to stop at a level crossing in Cambridgeshire.

item.title: VIDEO: Rare insight into Golden Dawn meeting
item.description: The BBC's Mark Lowen has a special report on Golden Dawn, Greece's far right party and hears from someone who attended one of their party meetings.

item.title: VIDEO: Cate Blanchett 'chuffed' at honour
item.description: Cate Blanchett has been honoured for her contribution to film culture at a special gala in New York

item.title: Freshers' fun? Not for the cleaners
item.description: Fun for students but not the university cleaners

item.title: Three leaders and their speeches compared
item.description: How the leaders' conference speeches measured up

item.title: Dambusters prepare for final tour
item.description: The RAF's Dambusters prepare for last deployment

item.title: Forty years of solitude
item.description: The US inmate freed after four decades in solitary

item.title: Can a drug make you tell the truth?
item.description: Can a powerful drug really stop you telling lies?

item.title: My grandfather would have shot me
item.description: The half-Nigerian who found out her grandfather was Amon Goeth

item.title: Analysis: Iraq’s never-ending security crisis
item.description: Examining surge in sectarian violence in Iraq

item.title: The man who shot Christine Keeler, and James Bond's pilot double
item.description: The man who shot Christine Keeler

item.title: Are the children of Birmingham safe tonight?
item.description: Keanu Williams case puts focus on child protection

item.title: Halt on BP payments to 'phony' oil-spill victims
item.description: BP spared compensation pay-out
